text.p: British auctioneers Sotheby's said on Thursday it had suspended some employees after allegations that Italian art treasures had been smuggled to London.
The managing director of Sotheby's Europe, George Bailey, told Britain's Press Association news agency he could not condone actions against the law or the firm's strict rules.
But he was strongly critical of the way the allegations had been made in an investigative television programme which used a hidden camera.
Bailey said he would make no final decision until he had seen the programme and made further investigations.
"If any Sotheby's employees have behaved illegally, as they may or may not have done, I will take the necessary action. I take my pride in our reputation, as my staff do," he said.
The programme is due to be screened on Britain's Channel 4 television on Thursday night.
Sotheby's issued a statement deploring the methods used for the investigation, which it said had deliberately enticed employees into breaching its strict procedures.
"Nevertheless, rules may have been broken and the staff concerned have been suspended pending a fuller investigation," said the statement.
"Such behaviour, if proven, does not represent the company's practices, nor will it be condoned by the company's management."
